beats.reasoning: Beat 1 is the downbeat of an intro with low energy; we use a subtle rotating wash to build tension without overwhelming the vocals. A single moving head provides gentle motion while a static cool color and spectrum-based intensity keeps the effect subdued yet engaging.

Intro section is low‑energy and calm; to keep the mood subtle we use a gentle Wave motion on a single moving head, with a cool static color and a matching intensity wave to add a hint of movement without overstimulation.

At ~1% of the track this is the intro, low‑energy, high‑frequency dominated section. According to professional rules, the intro should remain dark and subtle, with breathing room and no dramatic motion or VFX. Therefore this beat remains empty to build tension before the first lyrical phrases.

Intro section with low energy and high‑frequency content; professional rules advise minimal or no effects early on to build tension and allow breathing room. Following the 60–70 % sync rule, this beat is kept silent to avoid over‑loading the start of the track.

Intro, low energy and high‑band content suggests a subtle, cool wash. A single moving‑head with a mild wave motion and static cool color keeps the tension building without overwhelming the calm start.

Beat 6/208 falls early in the intro where energy is low and the goal is to build tension subtly. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the ‘less is more’ guideline for beginnings, this beat is left empty to allow a quiet, breathing space before later lighting cues build.

Beat 7/208 falls in the early intro where the track is still building tension with low energy and no strobe or high‑impact effects. To keep a subtle, cool wash and allow the music to breathe, this beat is left empty following the 60‑70% sync rule and intro‑style restraint.

Beat 8/208 falls in the intro where energy is low and the lyric is a gentle line.  To build subtle tension we use a single moving head with a slow wave motion, a cool static color wash, and a gentle intensity wave.  This keeps the lighting understated yet engaged, following the 60‑70% sync rule while avoiding over‑stimulation at the start.

Beat 9 is still within the intro section (~4% of the song). According to professional rules, the intro should remain subtle and build tension gradually, so providing breathing room with no effects aligns with the 60‑70% sync rule and avoids overwhelming the early, low‑energy atmosphere.

Beat 10/208 falls in the introductory phase—medium energy but still building tension. A single rotating light with a cool static color offers a subtle, non‑strobing cue that respects the 60‑70% sync rule while supporting the vocal line without overpowering the calm atmosphere.

Beat 11/208 falls in the intro, a low‑energy, high‑dominant section meant for subtle build‑up. A gentle wave on a single moving head keeps the motion restrained while still providing visual interest, aligning with the intro’s cool, calm aesthetic and the 60‑70% sync rule.

At ~5% of the track this is the intro, with low energy and lyric content. Professional practice calls for subtle, cool wash light and no VFX or strobe at this early stage, leaving room for build‑up. Therefore this beat remains empty to conserve the 60‑70% sync rule and maintain breathing space.

At ~6% of the track this is still early intro; energy is medium but the build is subtle. A gentle Wave motion on a single light group with a static cool wash supports the vocals without overpowering, keeping the intro restrained and allowing tension to rise.

Beat 14 sits in the early intro where energy is only medium and the track is still building tension; a single subtle motion keeps the atmosphere cool and restrained while following the 60‑70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 15/208 falls in the early intro, where the energy is only medium and the brightness is low; a subtle motion on a single light keeps the build without over‑dramatic impact. A gentle Wave motion with a cool static color and wave‑intensity effect provides a calm, supportive wash that follows the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 16/208 falls early in the intro; energy is medium but still building, so a subtle single‑light wash with gentle rotation provides breathing room while keeping a 60‑70% sync rate. No VFX or lasers are used to preserve the intro’s calm tone.

At ~8% of the track, beat 17 falls in the intro/early verse with medium but not high energy and a mid‑dominant band. To build tension gradually and avoid a robotic feel, this beat is left breathing room per the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro’s subtle, cool‑tone aesthetic.

At beat 18/208 the track is still in the intro, medium energy and high‑frequency content, but no drop yet. A subtle wave motion on a single moving head with a warm static color and wave‑intensity sync builds tension without overwhelming the early section, following the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding VFX on calm moments.

Beat 19 sits early in the intro where tension is building but still subtle; a gentle motion with a soft color wash supports the vocals without overpowering the low-energy section. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a single light group with a wave motion and steady blue tone provides breathing room while hinting at the upcoming energy lift.

Beat 20/208 falls in the early intro phase (~9%) with medium energy but not a climactic moment; professional rules call for minimal, subtle lighting to build tension. Leaving this beat empty provides breathing room and aligns with the 60‑70% sync strategy for intro sections.
Beat 21/208 falls early in the intro/verse with medium high‑band energy but no drop or key lyric cue; keeping it empty preserves subtle tension and follows the 60–70% sync rule for breathing room.

Beat 22 is low‑energy verse with steady vocal line; to keep a relaxed feel we provide breathing room and avoid adding motion. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style wash guidance, this beat remains empty.

Verse section with medium energy and vocal focus; we use a subtle LaserCone on the multi‑light group for a focused beam and a rotating single head to add movement without overwhelming the vocals. Both groups are synced to the downbeat to provide support while keeping the 60‑70% sync rate and avoiding excessive strobe or VFX.

Verse section with medium energy and high‑band emphasis; a gentle Wave motion on a single light supports the vocal line without overwhelming. Using a static warm color and ping‑pong intensity provides a subtle wash that keeps the groove alive while respecting the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 25 falls in the early verse, moderate energy and high‑frequency content. A subtle wave on a single moving head keeps the vocals supported without overpowering the mix, following the 60‑70% sync guideline and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 26 falls in a mid‑energy verse with vocal lyric support. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a single moving head providing a gentle Wave motion with warm static color and ping‑pong intensity gives subtle support without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 27 falls in the early verse with high energy but still under the vocal line. A subtle wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocals, while a laser fan adds a warm wash without dominating. This keeps the 60‑70% sync rule and follows the verse‑supporting aesthetic.

Verse section with high energy but not a drop; a moderate mix of motion and laser beams keeps the vocal support while avoiding over‑stimulation. A single moving head with a wave motion provides rhythmic support, and a synchronized laser cone adds visual interest without dominating.
Beat 29 sits in a mid‑energy verse where the focus is on vocals; to avoid over‑lighting and keep breathing room per the 60‑70% sync rule, no major effects are added.

Beat 30 falls in a verse section (~14% of the track) where vocals are foregrounded; although the bass energy is high, the overall energy is still moderate. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, we give a single head a subtle wave motion with a warm static color and spectrum‑based intensity to support the vocals without overpowering the mix.

Beat 31 falls in the early verse where the energy is high but still not at a drop; we add a subtle wave motion to support the vocal line while keeping the lighting breathy. A single moving head with a wave motion and a warm static color keeps the focus on the lyrics without overwhelming the mix.

Verse section, medium energy, mid‑band dominance and ongoing vocals – a gentle wave motion on a single moving head keeps the light field supportive without overpowering. A static color keeps focus on the words, while spectrum‑based intensity syncs with the music subtly, maintaining a 60‑70% sync rate for breathing room.

Beat 33 falls in the early verse (~15% of the track) where the energy is high but the section is still supportive of vocals. A single moving head with a gentle wave motion and a warm static color provides subtle accent without overpowering the lyrics, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the focus on the vocal line.

Beat 34 falls in the early verse section (≈16% of the song) with medium energy and a high‑frequency vocal line. To maintain breathing room while subtly supporting the vocals, a single moving‑head group is used with gentle wave motion, warm static color, and moderate intensity, following the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 35 falls in the mid‑verse, medium energy and moderate mid‑band presence. To support vocals without overwhelming, a single moving light with a gentle wave motion and a warm static color provides subtle movement and contrast, following the 60‑70% sync rule and verse‑style restraint.

Beat 36 falls in a verse with high energy and mid‑band dominance; we keep the show moving without the full intensity of a drop. Beat 37 is early in the verse with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals. A subtle rotating wash (SINGLE_LIGHT_GROUP) supports the vocals without overwhelming the calm mood, following the 60–70% sync rule and keeping the build gradual.

Beat 38 falls in the early verse where the energy is medium and the vocal line is being supported rather than highlighted. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a single gentle motion on a single light group provides subtle support without overwhelming the vocals or creating a strobing feel.

Beat 39 sits in the verse section, medium energy with a high‑band focus, so we use a subtle wave motion on a single moving head to support the vocals. A warm static color and ping‑pong intensity create breathing room while keeping the beat in sync with the 60‑70% rule.

Beat 40/208 falls in the mid‑verse with medium energy and high‑band emphasis, ideal for a subtle supportive motion rather than a full‑blown drop. A single moving‑head wave keeps the vocals in focus with a warm wash, providing breathing room while maintaining a 60‑70 % sync rate.

Beat 41 is the downbeat of bar 11 during a high‑energy verse dominated by bass; to support vocals without over‑stimulation we use a gentle Wave motion on a single moving head with a warm static color and modest ping‑pong intensity. Beat 42 sits in the middle of a verse with medium energy and high‑frequency instrumentation; a subtle laser cone provides a gentle accent that supports the vocals without overwhelming the calm section. Beat 46 falls in the first verse where energy is high but still supportive of vocals. A single moving head with a gentle wave motion and a warm static color adds subtle visual interest without overwhelming the mix, and the ping‑pong intensity keeps the light breathing in sync with the bass hits.

Beat 51 falls in a high‑energy verse where the vocalist is prominent; a gentle Wave motion on a single moving‑head supports the vocals without overpowering the mix. This beat falls in a high‑energy verse; we use a single moving head with a gentle Wave motion to support the vocal line without overwhelming it. Beat 53 falls in the early verse with medium energy and vocal focus. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, a gentle wave motion on a single moving head supports the vocals without overwhelming, using a warm static color and wave‑intensity to add subtle movement.

At ~26% of the track this is a high‑energy verse with strong bass. Rather than full‑on drop effects, we provide moderate motion: a LaserCone on the multi‑light group to echo the high‑frequency vocals and a Wave on a single light to accent the bass, keeping the verse supportive yet lively.

Beat 78 is in the pre‑chorus build‑up, with medium‑high energy and a dominant high‑frequency bass line, so we add subtle motion and color to ramp intensity toward the drop while keeping the arrangement breathing. At ~38% of the track this is a pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and a mid‑band focus. According to the 60‑70% sync rule, a single laser fan effect gives a sense of rising intensity without overwhelming the vocals, and the wave‑intensity adds subtle motion to keep the stage lively.

Beat 81/208 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up with medium energy and high‑frequency vocals. Beat 83 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up with high bass energy and vocal lyrics. To gradually raise the intensity, a laser cone on a multi‑light group syncs with the bass hits, while a static warm colour and a wave‑shaped intensity keeps the motion dynamic without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 84/208 sits in a build‑up phase with medium energy and high‑frequency vocal words; we add subtle laser fan motion to elevate the visual intensity while keeping the atmosphere controlled. Beat 85/208 falls in a low‑energy pre‑chorus section with mid‑band emphasis and no lyrical highlight; it is not a key climax moment, so breathing room is appropriate to maintain contrast and avoid robotic strobing.
Beat 86 falls in a low‑energy pre‑chorus section with vocal lyrics; the professional rule of leaving 30‑40% of beats empty for breathing room applies, so no effects are triggered here.

Beat 87 falls in the pre‑chorus build‑up; energy is low so we keep a subtle motion to support the vocal without overwhelming. A rotating single‑head light with a warm static color and spectrum‑based intensity gives a gentle build toward the upcoming drop.

Beat 88 is in a low‑energy pre‑chorus section with mid‑band emphasis and lyrical content that is not a climactic moment. Beat 90/208 falls early in the pre‑chorus with low energy and dominant high‑frequency content, but it is not a key lyrical moment or a build‑up peak. At beat 91 the song is still in the low‑energy build‑up section of the pre‑chorus; we want a subtle motion to hint at rising intensity without overwhelming vocals. Beat 92 is the downbeat of bar 23, a key moment in the pre‑chorus build‑up. With medium energy and bass‑dominance, a subtle laser cone provides a visual cue that the energy is rising without overwhelming the vocals. This follows the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps the progression natural.

At 44% of the track this is a pre‑chorus build‑up, high energy with strong bass.  We use lasers and a wave to raise intensity without full drop VFX, giving a dramatic lift while leaving some beats empty for breathing room.

Beat 94 sits in the pre‑chorus build‑up, medium energy and bass‑driven. We add a subtle wave motion on a single head (key 2) to support the bass line and a laser fan (key 4) to begin layering color dynamics without full drop intensity.

Beat 95/208 falls within the chorus/drop section (~45% of the track) but shows low energy and high‑frequency content, so a subtle but moving effect keeps the momentum without overwhelming the vocals. Beat 96 is low‑energy and just before the high‑energy drop, so providing breathing room aligns with the 60‑70% sync rule and keeps the transition natural. No VFX or motion is warranted here, keeping the focus on the upcoming chorus.

Beat 97/208 sits at the beginning of the chorus; medium energy but high‑frequency dominant signals a need for bright, focused lighting. Adding a laser cone (multi‑light group) emphasizes the high tones while a wave motion (single‑light group) supports the bass. Beat 98 falls in the mid‑song chorus/drop with high energy and a high‑frequency dominant band, so we use a VFX group for dramatic impact, laser cones/fans for bright beams, and a rotating single light for added motion—keeping only 4 of the 6 possible groups active to satisfy the 60‑70% sync rule.

Beat 99 sits on a high‑energy chorus drop (~47% of track). According to rules, the downbeat should trigger dramatic VFX and laser beams, but we limit effects to ~65% of beats for breathing room. Thus we enable a simultaneous VFX burst plus a LaserCone to emphasize the peak.

Beat 100/208 sits at the start of the chorus drop—high energy, dominant high-frequency content and a lyrical hook—so we activate a VFX wave, lasers, and rotating moving heads for maximum visual impact while keeping breathing room on other beats.

Beat 101/208 falls in the chorus/drop phase (~48% of the track) with high bass energy, so we use a full‑scale effect lineup. Beat 102 is a high‑energy bass‑dominant drop in the chorus, so we use a dramatic VFX burst (key 0) for the climactic moment, paired with synchronized laser cone (key 4) and rotating wash (key 2) to fill the beat while keeping 60–70 % of beats active for breathing room.

Beat 103/208 falls in a high‑energy drop; we use fireworks, lasers, and moving heads to energize the crowd while keeping 60‑70% of beats active. Five groups (VFX, two laser types, and two single‑head motions) give ~62.5% sync, providing impact yet breathing room.

Beat 104/208 lands in the chorus/drop with high bass energy and vocal lyrics, making it ideal for a full‑scale effect burst.
